1 - Introduction
The SCS Web Manager is a web interface that allows you to create/edit/delete connectors, register a GSA or an ftp server and configure the SCS authentication.
Connectors are pieces of software that are able to pull some information from an external system (CMS, DMS, CRM, LDAP, Database, ...).
In the SCS, connectors can support the following functionalities:
Authentication: Verifies the existence of a user in the external system. This is achieved either by retrieving the user name from a Kerberos challenge and checking that the user exists in the external system or by obtaining the user name and his password from a login form and checking this credential against the remote system.
Group retrieval: Retrieves the list of groups a given user belongs to.
Name transformation: Transforms a user name into another user name. A name transformer is necessary when a same user has different names in different systems and that we want to authenticate and/or retrieve the groups he belongs to for all these systems.
Late binding authorization: Verifies that a given user has READ permissions on a given set of resources.
2 - Configuration
Once the SCS initial setup is complete and that its license has been obtained from Sword and installed, open the SCS administration web interface from a web browser.
When prompted for authentication, you can either authenticate with the local SCSAdmin account (using the password you configured during the installation steps) or, once you have registered a GSA in the SCS, you can authenticate with a GSA admin account.
Registering a GSA could already have been done during the installation if you chose so.
Then create all the necessary connectors. Each connector creation/edition page contains in-context help and a link to the connector documentation.
When connectors have been created, you can configure authentication.
3 - GSA Configuration
When the SCS configuration is complete you can configure the SCS as:
  • A SAML provider if at least one of the connectors that are configured supports SAML authentication*1 or if the SCS was configured for Kerberos authentication.
  • A Cookie Cracker if at least one of the connectors that are configured supports Cookie Cracking authentication*1.
  • A Connector Manager. The SCS can always be configured as a Connector Manager.
*1: The list of authentication mechanisms supported by a
connector can be found in its documentation.
3.1 - Configuring a SAML provider
To configure the SCS as a SAML provider, connect to the GSA administration console and go to the Universal Login Auth Mechanisms section.
Click on the SAML tab.
Enter the following information:
Parameter nameDescription
Mechanism Name:
Any name that helps you identify what this authentication mechanism is used for.
IDP Entity ID:
Any string as long as it matches the Entity Id that you configured in the SCS administration web interface.
Login URL:
http(s)://<SCS host>:<SCS HTTP(S) port>/SCS/authenticate
Artifact Resolver URL:
Only for SAML Redirect-Binding: http(s)://<SCS host>:<SCS HTTP(S) port>/SCS/responder
Public Key of IDP:
Only for SAML Post-Binding: Enter the content of the SAML public key that you can export using the SCS management application.
3.2 - Configuring a Cookie Cracker
To configure the SCS as a Cookie Cracker, connect to the GSA administration console and go to the Universal Login Auth Mechanisms section.
Click on the Cookie tab.
Enter the following information:
Parameter nameDescription
Mechanism Name:
Any name that helps you identify what this authentication mechanism is used for.
Sample URL:
http(s)://<SCS host>:<SCS HTTP(S) port>/SCS/authenticate
Redirect URL:
The SCS does not support the use of this parameter.
Return URL:
Does not apply.
3.3 - Configuring a Connector Manager
To configure the SCS as a Connector Manager, connect to the GSA administration console and go to the Connector Managers section.
In the Register a New Connector Manager section, enter the following information:
Parameter nameDescription
Manager name:
Any name that helps you identify what this connector manager is used for.
Service URL:
http(s)://<SCS host>:<SCS HTTP(S) port>/SCS/connector-manager
With the SCS configured as a Connector Manager, you cannot add connectors or edit connectors configuration from the GSA administration console. SCS connectors management always has to be done using the SCS configuration web interface.
Consequently as soon as you register the SCS as a Connector Manager, the list of connectors you configured in the SCS configuration web interface is immediately displayed and you can start configuring connectors for authentication or group retrieval in the Universal Login Auth Mechanisms section of the GSA administration console.
4 - Add Connector Instance
  1. Go to the SCS Web manager interface tab Connector List and click on Add Connector:
  2. Select your connector type instance on the scrolling menu:
  3. Fill connector configuration before saving. You can find assistance for this part by looking at Connector documentation.
Once configured, you can manage your connector instance on Connector tab
On that menu you can perform the following tasks:
Configure: Modification of connector configuration
Monitor: This page displays indexing information on the connector. Many actions are available on that page such as:
  • Start and Stop connector
  • Reset the index
  • View Logs
  • View Indexing Internal state
Delete: Used to remove connector instance.
